Description: Axe-head: bound to its original haft. The blade is splayed and its cutting edge narrow. The sides are gently bevelled. The edge shows signs of wear. The piece is moderately corroded. Traces of matting are preserved in the corrosion product on one face. Chased on the other face is a hieroglyphic inscription. The haft was badly decayed on discovery and so was solidified with wax by the excavators. It is cracked through at one point and little of the original wood survives. The blade was secured to the haft by a plaited leather thong, which survives only on one side.

Kühnert-Eggesbrecht, ‘Die Axt als Waffe und Werkzeug im alten Ägypten’ (Berlin, 1969), 132, P 5, pl. XIX; M. Bietak and E. Strouhal, ‘Annalen des Naturhistorischen Museums in Wien’ 78 (Vienna, 1974), 38, 41, fig. 5; M. Bietak, ‘Studien zur Chronologie der Nubische C-Gruppe, Ein Beitrag zur Frühgeschichte Unternubiens zwischen 2200 und 1550 vor Chr.’ (Vienna, 1968), 150, n. 1177; M. Bietak, ‘Ausgrabungen in Sayala-Nubien 1961-75’ (Vienna, 1966), 72 and 76-7.
Bibliographic references: Davies 1987 / Catalogue of Egyptian Antiquities in the British Museum (102)
